channel.title: Ready Boost!
channel.description:
Do you have Vista? Are you a gamer? Does your Vista run slow? Do you have a memory stick or an MP3 player layign around in your house? If the answers to all those questions are yes then this is the thing for you. As many of you may know Vista is nothing but a Memory hog. Microsoft added a new and clever function to Windos Vista, this feature allows you to use a Memory stick or an old MP3 player as extra RAM for your computer. In order for your memory stick/MP3 player to work it needs to have the following:
512 MB of RAM (Recommended because this is what Vista needs to run) It needs to be able to read 3.5MB/s
If your memory stick or MP3 player meets those requirements then you may be able to use it. To begin plug in your device you are using into anempty USB port, then a little box should come up, click the button that says "Speed up My Computer"
Note: If this box doesn't come up go to My Computer, then right clikc your MP3 or memory stick and click properties, then go to the ReadyBoost tab.
Once you are on the ReadyBoost tab put the bar up to the max. And then click apply.
Note: The MP3 or memory stick should have nothing on it.

item.title: Ready Boost!
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

ThAt0n36Uy:

Flash memory can only be written on so many times. So once they reach the max, they can’t be written to anymore. They can also fail if they’re dropped, or shocked in some way, maybe by water.

My flash drive went through the wash… For some reason it wont work on macs anymore…

Read full topic

item.title: Ready Boost!
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Flashdrives don’t have a battery lol

The 10 years of life refers to the fact that you can write to them about a million times before they fail…guess you missed that part on wikipedia.

These products are typically used as low power, rugged replacements for hard drives, especially in installations exposed to extreme conditions. The flash memory cells tend to fail after around a million writes which made early devices unsuitable for storage which is often updated in place, such as swap files.

lol…battery…

Read full topic

item.title: Ready Boost!
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

all of these usb sticks have a really small battery. Try to take the ram chip off it and put it back on 10 secs later. You will need to format it again before you can use it.

Read full topic

item.title: Ready Boost!
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“magma828, post:1, topic:210306”]runescape3dude you can’t just take any old memory stick and solder it to the RAM slot. For a start memory sticks work in a completly different way because they can store data even when there is no power.

[mobosuicide][/quote]

Do not try this unless you have an old pc lieing around. I will not be responsible for your fuck ups. I am not in any way incouraging this method of ram installation. If you have any further queries, please hesitate to ask. Good-bye

Thats because they have batteries(really small(soldered onto the board))… Look at the box “10 years life”

Read full topic

item.title: Ready Boost!
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Why not just buy RAM…?

For 40$ you can get 2GB of RAM off Newegg that’s what 2 flash drives?

Edit: If this is just adding swap…that’s completely useless to me…

Screenshot-SystemMonitor.png606×528

I’ve never dented my swap on ArchLinux, and when I had Xp I’m pretty sure I hardly did after adding that RAM

EditEdit:
And of course this is also possible for Linux XD
Its just called “SwapBoost” although it is in its early stages. Most likely won’t ever come out of early stages because no one needs an extra boost for Linux =P

Read full topic
